node.title: Error in installing MOOSE.
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
hello,
i am facing this error while installing MOOSE.
(base) snehad@ubuntu:~$ conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.08.30 mpich
Channels:

https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
conda-forge
Platform: linux-64
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): failed

UnavailableInvalidChannel: HTTP 403 FORBIDDEN for channel public https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
The channel is not accessible or is invalid.
You will need to adjust your conda configuration to proceed.
Use conda config --show channels to view your configuration's current state,
and use conda config --show-sources to view config file locations.

This is tied to our new use of cloudyflare
@milljm
Works for me... Both while at home and at work. As well as from my cell phone.
same for me. But this is the 3rd poster reporting this
This is probably due to their country of origin blocking outbound traffic. Not us blocking them.

from the other post, when they reach the website on a browser they get a "are you human" challenge. They can pass it in the browser. conda cant.
It can also be cloudflare treating other countries differently
Okay, yeah that was helpful. I am in contact with our Cloudflare team. I am asking that this "feature" be disabled.
I have been told this was fixed yesterday at 14:30 MST.

node.title: UnavailableInvalidChannel: HTTP 403 FORBIDDEN for channel public <https://conda.software.inl.gov/public>
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
Failed to create the conda environment fro Moose.
UnavailableInvalidChannel: HTTP 403 FORBIDDEN for channel public https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
(Optional) code in question / simulation log / errors
No response
Encountering Errors? Please include diagnostic output
No response

hello
Can you please try again now? There are network flukes

It is still happening. So, I was trying to make some other environments for my personal work like 2-3 days agao and since this "https://conda.software.inl.gov/public" is already added, it gave the same error then too. I had to disable it for my other environment to run.
I tested just now, and it is still giving the same error.
(base) xyz@xyz-abc:~$ conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.08.30 mpich
Channels:

https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
conda-forge
Platform: linux-64

Use conda config --show channels to view your configuration's current state,
and use conda config --show-sources to view config file locations.

Also, when we try to open the website, we have to solve Cloudflare verifier:

So, this is happening due to a Cloudflare protection layer on the MOOSE public Conda channel. When accessing it via the browser, we are completing the JavaScript-based security challenge (as shown above, which checks for bots), but when conda or curl tries to access the channel, it cannot complete this challenge and therefore results in a 403 "Forbidden" error.

This is a recent change.
Tagging @milljm @loganharbour for awareness
A tentative workaround for now is to download the (moose-dev & dependencies) packages from your browser then install offline
>conda install --offline <path to package>

you ll still want to be online to install all the dependencies from conda-forge
I do have the same problem. How to install MOOSE with this forbidden error?
Not a solution, but can you peruse to the following sites, which were also moved over to cloudflare services? https://civet.inl.gov, https://mooseframework.inl.gov

@Aayush-T, Thank you for posting! I didn't read your entire post enough to realize the server was accessible only after authenticating as a human.
I am in contact with our Cloudflare team to try and get this "feature" disabled.
I have been told this was fixed yesterday at 14:30 MST.

node.title: <Use a descriptive title here>
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello I want to compute this Diffusion. Sorry forgot write title😹
$J_{Cs} = -D_{Cs} \nabla C_{Cs} - D_{Cs} C_{Cs} \frac{Q_{Cs}}{R T^2} \nabla T $
$\frac{\partial C_{Cs}}{\partial t} = - \nabla \cdot J_{Cs} + Y_{Cs} \dot{F} $
Here is week form:
Multiply by a test function $v$ and integrate over the domain:
$\int_\Omega \frac{\partial C_{Cs}}{\partial t} v , d\Omega = - \int_\Omega \nabla \cdot J_{Cs} v , d\Omega + \int_\Omega Y_{Cs} \dot{F} v , d\Omega $
Apply the divergence theorem to transform the second term:
$\int_\Omega \frac{\partial C_{Cs}}{\partial t} v , d\Omega = \int_{\partial \Omega} J_{Cs} \cdot n v , d\Gamma - \int_\Omega J_{Cs} \cdot \nabla v , d\Omega + \int_\Omega Y_{Cs} \dot{F} v , d\Omega$
Here, $J_{Cs} \cdot n$ is the flux at the boundary $\partial \Omega$, which is specified by boundary conditions.
Substitute the expression for $J_{Cs}$
$J_{Cs} = -D_{Cs} \nabla C_{Cs} - D_{Cs} C_{Cs} \frac{Q_{Cs}}{R T^2} \nabla T $
Substituting this into the weak form:
$\int_\Omega \frac{\partial C_{Cs}}{\partial t} v , d\Omega = \int_{\partial \Omega} (-D_{Cs} \nabla C_{Cs} - D_{Cs} C_{Cs} \frac{Q_{Cs}}{R T^2} \nabla T) \cdot n v , d\Gamma- \int_\Omega (-D_{Cs} \nabla C_{Cs} - D_{Cs} C_{Cs} \frac{Q_{Cs}}{R T^2} \nabla T) \cdot \nabla v , d\Omega+ \int_\Omega Y_{Cs} \dot{F} v , d\Omega$
Boundary Conditions :
For the boundary conditions:


$$J_{Cs} = 0$$ at $$z = 0$$ and $$z = L$$ (no-flux boundary condition).

These translate into:

For $$z = 0$$ and $$z = L$$, the flux term $$J_{Cs} \cdot n = 0$$, meaning the surface integral on those boundaries will vanish.

For equations with a time derivative term (in your case for both the temperature and the oxygen concentration), you don't need any boundary condition to remove the singular values. However, according to what you showed us earlier, there are 221 singular values out of the total 602 dofs, which is interesting. Can you report back the number of singular values with and without the time derivative kernel for concentration?
I also noticed that you are using a time derivative coefficient for concentration that is on the order of 10^28, which is astronomically large compared to the that of temperature. Therefore, you are essentially numerically removing the time derivative kernel for the temperature (as it becomes negligible compared to the time derivative of concentration), and I suspect that's the source of the 221 singular values. Try to use time derivative coefficients for the two equations that are on the same order of magnitude, and see if that gets rid of the singular values.
You are also using coord_type = RZ on a 1D mesh. I am not sure what the implications are, but I suggest you either change the coord_type to RSpherical, or use a 2D mesh.

node.title: Question on outputing directions of max and min principal stress
node.bodyText:
I output max and min principal stress by using [AuxVariables] and [AuxKernels] ("Rank Two Aux") based on the example at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/RankTwoAux.html
> [AuxVariables]
>   [./maxprincipal]
>     order = CONSTANT
>     family = MONOMIAL
>   [../]
>   [./minprincipal]
>     order = CONSTANT
>     family = MONOMIAL
>   [../]
> [] # AuxVariables
> 
> [AuxKernels]
>   [./maxprincipal]
>     type = RankTwoScalarAux
>     rank_two_tensor = stress
>     variable = maxprincipal
>     scalar_type = MaxPrincipal
>   [../]
>   [./minprincipal]
>     type = RankTwoScalarAux
>     rank_two_tensor = stress
>     variable = minprincipal
>     scalar_type = MinPrincipal
>   [../]
> [] # AuxKernels

However, there is no example telling how the directions of principle stress are output. I found a website that seems to be the source code relevant to "Rank Two Aux" at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classRankTwoTensorTempl.html#ade890b615f07c8adb12b4dfa647f2fcd
In the source, Eigenvalues (principle stress) and Eigenvectors (direction of principle stress) are calcualted as by a function called "symmetricEigenvaluesEigenvectors()"
> void RankTwoTensorTempl< T >::symmetricEigenvaluesEigenvectors	
> (
> std::vector< T > & eigvals,
> RankTwoTensorTempl< T > & eigvecs 
> )		const
> computes eigenvalues and eigenvectors, assuming tens is symmetric, and places them in ascending order in eigvals.
> eigvecs is a matrix with the first column being the first eigenvector, the second column being the second, etc.
> Definition at line 866 of file RankTwoTensorImplementation.h.
>   868 {
>   869   mooseError(
>   870       "symmetricEigenvaluesEigenvectors is only available for ordered tensor component types");
>   871 }

I want to ask
1.	How can I find all the parameters that “RankTwoScalarAux” can calculate and output, along with their corresponding “name” in the syntax?
2.	When I locate a function in the C++ source code, how can I relate it to the corresponding MOOSE syntax?

Hello
The parameters are listed at the bottom of every object documentation page. Here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/RankTwoScalarAux.html
If you are looking for the source for that object, it's there. You have to look in auxkernels and the module that it is a part of
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/solid_mechanics/src/auxkernels/RankTwoScalarAux.C
The parameters are in the validParams static function of every class in MOOSE. The input file is parsed by the Parser and the Builder in moose (internal objects, which you can examine if you are comfortable with C++).
The input syntax is fairly simple, it s usually:
params.addParam<type>("name_param", default_value, "documentation string");

this translates to:
[system of the object]
  [name for the object]
    type = <type of the object>
    name_param = some user selected value

pretty much the same way for every parameter
good question!

node.title: CP maximum allowable slip rate
node.bodyText:
Hello, I am running a compression test on a cylindre with 300 grains, a mesh with 111,000 DoF, a height of 72 mm. I want to reach 2% strain I have set the forced displacement at 10^-5 * t and a time step to reach a maximum of 72 (starting at 1 with the help of timestepper) but I keep getting warnings of the form of : 'Maximum allowed slip increment exceeded'. I've set the slip increment to 10. Is there a way to calibrate this slip increment value to optimize the time step and loading rate and still not have to wait forever to reach at least 1% strain. Thanks !!
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Mesh]
  [file]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = n300-id1.msh
  []
  [sidesets]
    type = SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator
    input =file
    normals = '0 0 -1
                0 0 1'
    fixed_normal = true
    new_boundary = 'bottom top'
  []
[]


[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic/all]
  strain = FINITE
  add_variables = true
  save_in = 'resid_x resid_y resid_z'
[]

[BCs]
  [symmy]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0
  []
  [symmx]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0
  []
  [symmz]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0
  []
  [tdisp]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = top
    function = '-1e-5*t'
  []
[]

[UserObjects]
  [prop_read]
    type = PropertyReadFile
    prop_file_name = 'input_euler.txt'
    nprop =4
    ngrain = 300
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorCP
    C_ijkl = '48.7e3 11.9e3 11.9e3 48.7e3 11.9e3 48.7e3 13.1e3 13.1e3 13.1e3'
    fill_method = symmetric9
    read_prop_user_object = prop_read
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress
    crystal_plasticity_models = 'trial_xtalpl'
    tan_mod_type = exact
    maximum_substep_iteration = 10
  []
  [trial_xtalpl]
    type = CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate
    number_slip_systems = 12
    slip_sys_file_name = input_slip_sys.txt
    ao = 2e-3
    gss_a = 2
    gss_initial = 10
    h = 100
    r = 1.4
    xm = 0.1
    t_sat = 100.
    resistance_tol = 1.0
    print_state_variable_convergence_error_messages = true
    slip_increment_tolerance = 10
  []
[]


[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_type -ksp_gmres_restart'
  petsc_options_value = ' lu       gmres     200'
  solve_type = NEWTON
  automatic_scaling = true
  line_search = 'none'
  dtmin = 5e-12
  dtmax = 72
  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 1 # Initial time step.  In this simulation it changes.
        cutback_factor = 0.25
     growth_factor = 1.2
     optimal_iterations = 20
  [../]
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_max_its = 20
  end_time = 6e5 
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  interval = 70
[]

Also the dt stopped increasing at 16.5618 is there a way to have better convergence and increase time step.

Hello
Do you mean the mesh has 110,000 cells? The number of dofs is tied to the number of variables. what does the simulation summary say for the number of DOFs?
Above 100k dofs it may be time to look at improving the preconditioning.

Mesh:
  Parallel Type:           replicated
  Mesh Dimension:          3
  Spatial Dimension:       3
  Nodes:
    Total:                 37330
    Local:                 1438
    Min/Max/Avg:           1005/1520/1244
  Elems:
    Total:                 90191
    Local:                 3093
    Min/Max/Avg:           2919/3096/3006
  Num Subdomains:          300
  Num Partitions:          30
  Partitioner:             metis

Nonlinear System:
  Num DOFs:                111990
  Num Local DOFs:          4314
  Variables:               { "disp_x" "disp_y" "disp_z" }
  Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE"
  Approximation Orders:    "FIRST"

I have 111.9k DoF which is relatively small for a cp computation. What do you mean by improving the preconditioning

Using a different solver package for LU or finding a different method
I wonder if you are using too many processors at this point. 4k dofs per processor is not a lot. Can you try using half as many processors to see if the performance improves?
Tried using mumps and 10 processors but it still takes too long.. 25min for 0.0025% strain

You've identified the correct parameter to adjust for the slip tolerance, and here's the context in case that helps you decide how much more you want to increase that value:

  
    
      moose/modules/solid_mechanics/src/materials/crystal_plasticity/CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate.C
    
    
         Line 99
      in
      ad167a6
    
  
  
    

        
          
           if (std::abs(_slip_increment[_qp][i]) * _substep_dt > _slip_incr_tol) 
        
    
  


I usually balance between the slip increment tolerance, slip_increment_tolerance, (and when appropriate the state variable tolerance, stol, and the slip resistance tolerance, resistance_tol) and the maximum_substep_iteration, but I don't have a good optimization procedure. I have found that keep the maximum_substep_iteration at or below 5 seems to help; after more than 5 substeps the simulations seem to slow down noticeably.
Ok thank you. Keeping maximum_substep_iteration below 5 has helped the most.

You may also like to look into the NEML2 submodule (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/solid_mechanics/NEML2.html), which does have full derivatives of the model terms through libTorch. @hugary1995 can better describe the capabilities of NEML2 than I can

node.title: Should Moose check block-restriction in FEProblemBase::duplicateVariableCheck

node.bodyText:
Hello
If you want the message to be more verbose and give more information (such as the block restriction) then that would work for us. Already it says "different type" but it would help the user to say which types are involved
However we can't really allow the check to let two "identical" variables be added without some serious checking. There are many variable parameters, we would have to check them all, not just the block restriction.
Guillaume
I'll try to prepare an PR.

node.title: Error while run tests after updates
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
After updating conda moose environment and get the latest updates for moose, I got the following error message while trying to run_test.
:241: RuntimeWarning: compile time version 3.10 of module 'hit' does not match runtime version 3.11
Segmentation fault: 11
Any help on having the issue solved will be much appreciated.

Hello
The hit warning could be red herring
Let's run a single input for example in test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion and see if the error can be isolated there

I run the test as
../../../moose_test-opt -i simple_diffusion.i
and got the following error
Illegal instruction: 4
BTW, I'm running MacOS Sonoma version14.6.1 (23G93).

ugh. This does not give us much
Is this a fresh install? If not then I would git clean -xfD the repo (in moose/) then try again
If so, then we ll need to run a debugger and hope we get better information
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html

I wonder if this could be folks performing an update with Conda, getting the OpenMPI compilers by accident, and running MOOSE which has some stale libs built with MPICH.
I think what @GiudGiud mentioned is the right approach. Clean the build, and build anew. But let's also make sure that you are using the 'better' stack. Can you perform the following and report back:
conda activate moose
condo list | grep moose

I did rebuild after clean -xdf, even reinstalled moose and conda. The issue now changed to all tests failed and when ran the simple_diffusion.i test, got the same error. Here is what returned after running 'conda list | grep moose':
moose-dev                 2024.07.27                mpich    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh             2024.07.27              mpich_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh-vtk         9.3.0                   mpich_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-mpi                 2024.07.10                mpich    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-peacock             2024.07.10              mpich_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-petsc               3.20.3                  mpich_1    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-tools               2024.07.19      py311h09a46a1_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-wasp                2024.05.08              build_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public

I think this qualifies for running the diagnostic script in its more "troubleshooting" fashion. To see if this machine is having other more serious issues, or if this is an environment issue.
cd ~/projects/moose/scripts
export METHOD=opt METHODS=opt MOOSE_JOBS=6
./diagnostics.sh --full-build
Diagnostics will attempt to do everything in a clean environment, all in a temp directory, from scratch. So it may take a while. But it will help tell us if building and running moose is even possible on this machine.
Edit:
I am running this on my own, as it's been a while... and I seem to hit a snag when building libMesh. Might happen to you. Working on a fix.
Edit:
If you are running into an issue with the above (failing to build libMesh) try modifying the moose/scripts/diagnostics.sh script like so:
at line (241) 
  
    
      moose/scripts/diagnostics.sh
    
    
         Line 241
      in
      e0de659
    
  
  
    

        
          
           MOOSE_PACKAGES="${MPI_PACKAGES} packaging pyaml jinja2 python" 
        
    
  


-MOOSE_PACKAGES="${MPI_PACKAGES} packaging pyaml jinja2 python"
+MOOSE_PACKAGES="${MPI_PACKAGES} zlib packaging pyaml jinja2 python"
(add zlib to the list)

I can run the diagnostics without any changes to the file. But it completed with 7 tests failed, all of which are for the web_server_control:
controls/web_server_control.get_postprocessor ................................................. FAILED (CRASH)
controls/web_server_control.connect_port ...................................................... FAILED (CRASH)
controls/web_server_control.errors/set_controllable_no_exist ................. FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)
controls/web_server_control.errors/postprocessor_no_exist .................... FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)
controls/web_server_control.errors/set_controllable_unregistered_type ........ FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)
controls/web_server_control.errors/set_controllable_bad_convert_json ......... FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)
controls/web_server_control.errors/set_controllable_vector_non_array ......... FAILED (EXPECTED ERROR MISSING)

Yeah that's normal (the web server tests failing).
Okay, looks like this means there is going to be something in your environment causing the failures.
We will need to take a closer look at the difference between these two environments:
Open a new terminal and:
conda activate moose
env | sort > ~/bad_env
And this environment
/usr/bin/env -i bash --norc --noprofile
# do the bits to manually source the conda environment. Just a guess if you installed
# Miniforge as described on our wiki to the letter:
export PATH=~/miniforge/bin:$PATH
source activate ~/miniforge/envs/moose
env | sort > ~/good_env
And then compare the two:
sdiff ~/good_env ~/bad_env
There is no miniforge directory on my computer, and only miniconda3.

In your case then:
/usr/bin/env -i bash --norc --noprofile
export PATH=~/miniconda3/bin:$PATH
source activate ~/miniconda3/envs/moose
env | sort > ~/good_env
This is the comparison result:

I ran through the same issue when I updated my moose and conda. Initially, I was getting the segmentation fault. Then I tried updating running ./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh, ./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh and update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh which led me to this error while running ./run_tests: Logfile.txt. Seems like libMesh could not locate the VTK.
@hchen139 Could you find any solution?

@MinMorsh, your issue not related to Illegal instruction: 4. Please begin a new discussion (if you already have, I apologize... I am simply addressing discussions as I receive them in my email). Your issue is a simple one as well, which I cannot answer here (cannot mark my post as answering this thread as it does not pertain to the original post).

I think I have a possible explanation for this, with a fix in libMesh/libmesh#3940
I'll post a further update once the fix is downstream and we have conda modules with it ready for testing.

The fix is now in all branches of moose. If you update with
conda install moose-dev=2024.08.30 mpich

then:

save all your work in moose
go to moose/
git clean -Xfd
then recompile with make
you should get working binaries
Problem solved! Much appreciated for the help to the team.

Older versions of conda are insanely slow with many packages. The new ones are fine. This is why we switched to mamba and then back to conda

Prompted by your comment above on conda being slow, and from a bit of googling, I see this is not unusual.  To get this to work quicker, could I retry with mamba, or is there a way I can force conda to update to version 24.7.1?

so this does not work?
 conda install conda=24.7.1
You can try with mamba if you would like
it's just conda install mamba then open a new tab then mamba install ...
note that sometimes it s easier to remove the miniconda/miniforge directory and re-download everything from this page
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
It mostly removes any long dependency solve

There is sometimes not an update path forward available for your installation of Conda. I have found this to be the case in the most recent upgrade process (from 23 to 24).
The solution in this case is to completely delete your current installation of Conda and install anew:
rm -rf ~/miniforge

# Linux
# curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-Linux-x86_64.sh

# Intel Mac
#curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-MacOSX-x86_64.sh

# Apple Si Mac
# curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-MacOSX-arm64.sh

bash Miniforge3-the-thing-you-downloaded-above -b -p ~/miniforge
exit
And then re-open your terminal window(s). No need to run conda init routines as those functions are already present in your shell profile.
At this point, it doesn't hurt to perform an update in the base environment:
conda activate base
conda update --all --yes
Finally, you should be able to install (quickly) the desired Conda packages.
We're still working on getting the "Illegal Instruction" issue solved...

That's fixed it!  New conda installation.  Moose reinstalled using latest August version with no errors and test passed.  My application updated and now running a model.  (Sort of - it isn't coverging, but fixing that is something I can try to sort out myself.)
Thank you so much!
